natural problem: A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction.
natural solution: The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chosen_number :: nat and expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "chosen_number \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "chosen_number \<le> 4"
and h2 : "expected_return = ((1/4) * (1/4) * 2) + ((1/4) * (3/4) * 1) + ((3/4) * (3/4) * (-1))"
shows  "expected_return = (-1) / 16"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes chosen_number :: nat and expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "chosen_number \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "chosen_number \<le> 4"
and h2 : "expected_return = ((1/4) * (1/4) * 2) + ((1/4) * (3/4) * 1) + ((3/4) * (3/4) * (-1))"
shows  "expected_return = (-1) / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose you have a game where you can choose a number between 1 and 4 (inclusive). The expected return for the game is calculated as follows: if you choose a number between 1 and 2 (probability of 1/4), you win double your bet (2 times your bet); if you choose a number between 2 and 3 (probability of 1/4), you win back your bet (1 times your bet); and if you choose a number between 3 and 4 (probability of 3/4), you lose your bet (-1 times your bet). Find the expected return for this game. The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "expected_return = (\<Sum>(x,y) \<in> {(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(1,4),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(2,4),
                                          (3,1),(3,2),(3,3),(3,4),(4,1),(4,2),(4,3),(4,4)}.
                                         (case (x,y) of
                                            (1,1) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (1,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (1,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (1,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,2) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (2,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,3) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (3,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,4) \<Rightarrow> 2)) / 16"
shows  "expected_return = (-1) / 16"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "expected_return = (\<Sum>(x,y) \<in> {(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(1,4),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(2,4),
                                          (3,1),(3,2),(3,3),(3,4),(4,1),(4,2),(4,3),(4,4)}.
                                         (case (x,y) of
                                            (1,1) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (1,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (1,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (1,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,2) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (2,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (2,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (3,3) \<Rightarrow> 2
                                          | (3,4) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,1) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,2) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,3) \<Rightarrow> 1
                                          | (4,4) \<Rightarrow> 2)) / 16"
shows  "expected_return = (-1) / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a game, you are given a grid with 4 rows and 4 columns (16 cells). The cells are labeled with the following rewards: 2 for (1,1), (2,2), (3,3), and (4,4); 1 for all other cells. Calculate the expected return (average reward) of the game when you pick one cell randomly. The final answer is $\frac{-1}{16}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "expected_return = -1/16"
shows  "\<forall> player_choice. player_choice \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<longrightarrow> 
  (1 / 16) * (-1) + (1 / 4) * 1 + (1 / 4) * 2 = expected_return"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "expected_return = -1/16"
shows  "\<forall> player_choice. player_choice \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<longrightarrow> 
  (1 / 16) * (-1) + (1 / 4) * 1 + (1 / 4) * 2 = expected_return"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A game has four possible outcomes, with probabilities 1/16, 1/4, 1/4, and 1/4 for outcomes 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. The expected return for each outcome is -1, 1, 2, and the expected return for the game is -1/16. What is the expected return for outcome 4?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes player_choice :: nat and dice1 dice2 :: nat and expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "player_choice \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h1 : "dice1 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h2 : "dice2 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h3 : "expected_return =
  (if player_choice = dice1 \<and> player_choice \<noteq> dice2 then 1
   else if player_choice = dice1 \<and> player_choice = dice2 then 2
   else -1) / 16"
shows  "expected_return = -1/16"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes player_choice :: nat and dice1 dice2 :: nat and expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "player_choice \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h1 : "dice1 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h2 : "dice2 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h3 : "expected_return =
  (if player_choice = dice1 \<and> player_choice \<noteq> dice2 then 1
   else if player_choice = dice1 \<and> player_choice = dice2 then 2
   else -1) / 16"
shows  "expected_return = -1/16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a game, a player chooses a number from 1 to 4, and two dice with faces numbered 1 to 4 are rolled. The player's expected return is calculated as follows: if the player's chosen number matches one of the dice and not the other, the return is 1; if the player's chosen number matches both dice, the return is 2; otherwise, the return is -1. What is the player's expected return, given that each possible outcome has an equal probability of occurring? The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes exp_return :: real
assumes h0 : "exp_return = (1/4 * 1 + 1/16 * 2 - (11/16) * 1)"
shows  "exp_return = -1/16"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes exp_return :: real
assumes h0 : "exp_return = (1/4 * 1 + 1/16 * 2 - (11/16) * 1)"
shows  "exp_return = -1/16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Calculate the expected return, given the formula: $exp\_return = \frac{1}{4} * 1 + \frac{1}{16} * 2 - \frac{11}{16} * 1$. The final answer is $- \frac{1}{16}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_win_1 p_win_2 p_lose :: real
assumes h0 : "p_win_1 = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_win_2 = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "p_lose = 9 / 16"
shows  "1 * p_win_1 + 2 * p_win_2 - 1 * p_lose = -1 / 16"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_win_1 p_win_2 p_lose :: real
assumes h0 : "p_win_1 = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_win_2 = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "p_lose = 9 / 16"
shows  "1 * p_win_1 + 2 * p_win_2 - 1 * p_lose = -1 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a game, the probability of winning in the first round is $\frac{1}{2}$, the probability of winning in the second round is $\frac{1}{16}$, and the probability of losing is $\frac{9}{16}$. Calculate the expression $1 \times p_{win\_1} + 2 \times p_{win\_2} - 1 \times p_{lose}$. The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.

a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: real
assumes h0 : "E = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}. 
             (1/16 * 1) + (1/4 * 2) - (9/16 * 1))"
shows  "E = -1 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the value of the expression $E$, where $E$ is the sum of the following four terms: $\frac{1}{16} \cdot 1$, $\frac{1}{4} \cdot 2$, $-\frac{9}{16} \cdot 1$, and $0$. The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_single prob_double prob_none expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "prob_single = 1 / 8"
and h1 : "prob_double = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "prob_none = 5 / 16"
and h3 : "expected_return = prob_single * 1 + prob_double * 2 - prob_none * 1"
shows  "expected_return = -1 / 16"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_single prob_double prob_none expected_return :: rat
assumes h0 : "prob_single = 1 / 8"
and h1 : "prob_double = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "prob_none = 5 / 16"
and h3 : "expected_return = prob_single * 1 + prob_double * 2 - prob_none * 1"
shows  "expected_return = -1 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A game has three possible outcomes: single win, double win, and no win. The probability of a single win is $\frac{1}{8}$, the probability of a double win is $\frac{1}{16}$, and the probability of no win is $\frac{5}{16}$. If a player wins a single, they gain 1 point; if they win a double, they gain 2 points; and if they don't win, they lose 1 point. What is the expected return (in points) for playing this game? The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_return :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_return = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..4}. (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..4}. (\<Sum>l \<in> {1..4}.
    (if n = k \<and> n = l then 2 / 64
     else if (n = k \<and> n \<noteq> l) \<or> (n \<noteq> k \<and> n = l) then 1 / 64
     else -1 / 64))))"
shows  "expected_return = -1 / 16"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_return :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_return = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..4}. (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..4}. (\<Sum>l \<in> {1..4}.
    (if n = k \<and> n = l then 2 / 64
     else if (n = k \<and> n \<noteq> l) \<or> (n \<noteq> k \<and> n = l) then 1 / 64
     else -1 / 64))))"
shows  "expected_return = -1 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
In a game, there are four equally likely outcomes numbered from 1 to 4. A player's return is calculated as follows:

- If all three outcomes are the same, the return is $2/64$.
- If exactly two outcomes are the same, the return is $1/64$.
- If no two outcomes are the same, the return is $-1/64$.

Find the expected return of the game. The final answer is $-1/16$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_single_win P_double_win P_loss :: real
assumes h0 : "P_single_win = 2 / 16"
and h1 : "P_double_win = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "P_loss = 13 / 16"
shows  "expected_return = (P_single_win * 1) + (P_double_win * 2) - (P_loss * 1) = -1/16"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A player chooses one of the numbers 1 through 4. After the choice has been made, two regular four-sided (tetrahedral) dice are rolled, with the sides of the dice numbered 1 through 4. If the number chosen appears on the bottom of exactly one die after it is rolled, then the player wins $\$1.$ If the number chosen appears on the bottom of both of the dice, then the player wins $\$2.$ If the number chosen does not appear on the bottom of either of the dice, the player loses $\$1.$ What is the expected return to the player, in dollars, for one roll of the dice? Give your answer as a fraction. The final Answer is -\frac{1}{16}
 ### Proof
 The probability of the number appearing 0, 1, and 2 times is \begin{align} &P(0) = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{9}{16},\\ &P(1) = 2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{16}, \quad\text{and}\\
 &P(2) = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{16}, \end{align} respectively.
 So the expected return, in dollars, to the player is \begin{align} P(0)\cdot (-1) + P(1)\cdot (1) + P(2)\cdot (2) &= \frac{-9 + 6 + 2}{16} \\ &= \boxed{-\frac{1}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P_single_win P_double_win P_loss :: real
assumes h0 : "P_single_win = 2 / 16"
and h1 : "P_double_win = 1 / 16"
and h2 : "P_loss = 13 / 16"
shows  "expected_return = (P_single_win * 1) + (P_double_win * 2) - (P_loss * 1) = -1/16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a game, the probability of winning a single prize is $\frac{2}{16}$, the probability of winning a double prize is $\frac{1}{16}$, and the probability of losing is $\frac{13}{16}$. Calculate the expected return of the game, where winning a single prize gives you 1 point, winning a double prize gives you 2 points, and losing takes away 1 point. The final answer is $-\frac{1}{16}$.
